Below are recent, relevant papers returned by a literature search (2022–2025). I include title, authors, publication date, link (DOI/URL returned by the search tool), a short excerpt/summary from the tool output, and images when available.

### 1) Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons

- **Published:** 2024-12-18

- **Summary (excerpt):** All-optical approach to monitor spatiotemporal tuning and synaptic weight changes of dendritic spines before and after place-field induction in CA1 pyramidal neurons during navigation. Identifies a temporally asymmetric plasticity kernel and compartment-specific differences (basal vs oblique dendrites).  
- **Figure:**  
  ![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-08325-9/MediaObjects/41586_2024_8325_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 2) Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus  
- **Authors:** Magee, Jeffrey C. (result lists Magee)  
- **Published:** 2025-06-04  
- **Link:** [Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01986-3)  
- **Summary (excerpt):** Longitudinal tracking of CA1 place cells over 7 days during learning. Evidence that both the number of stable place cells and their stability increase across days; behavioral-timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP) accompanies place-cell formation and retrieval.  
- **Figure:**  
  ![Figure from paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01986-3/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1986_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 3) Synaptic plasticity and mental health: methods, challenges and opportunities  
- **Authors:** Lawrence G. Appelbaum, Mohammad Ali Shenasa, Louise Stolz, Zafiris Daskalakis  
- **Published:** 2022-10-17 (Neuropsychopharmacology)

- **Summary (excerpt):** Review of mechanisms of plasticity across scales and a survey of measurement techniques (structural imaging, hemodynamic measures, neuromodulation) relevant to synaptic plasticity and psychiatric disorders.

---

- **Authors:** Martin Stacho & Denise Manahan-Vaughan  
- **Published:** 2022-04-25  
- **Link:** [The Intriguing Contribution of Hippocampal Long-Term Depression to Spatial Learning and Long-Term Memory](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fnbeh.2022.806356/pdf)  
- **Summary (excerpt):** Review focused on hippocampal LTD (long-term depression), its roles in spatial learning, memory retention of content details, spine pruning, and interaction with LTP for pattern separation.

---

### 5) Editorial: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of synaptic plasticity at hippocampal and cortical synapses  
- **Authors:** Nathalia Vitureira, Roberto De Pasquale, Ricardo M. Leão, Francesco Mattia Rossi (editorial)  
- **Published:** 2022-07-15  
- **Link:** [Editorial: Cellular and molecular mechanisms of synaptic plasticity at hippocampal and cortical synapses](https://www.frontiersin.org/articles/10.3389/fncel.2022.980623/pdf)  
- **Summary (excerpt):** Editorial for a Research Topic that highlights current directions and open questions in cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying hippocampal and cortical plasticity, including LTP, LTD, STDP, homeostatic plasticity.

---

### 6) Modulation of hippocampal plasticity in learning and memory (PubMed entry)  
- **Authors:** Tanja Fuchsberger, Ole Paulsen  
- **Published:** 2022 (PubMed entry)  
- **Link:** [PubMed: Modulation of hippocampal plasticity in learning and memory](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/35660989/)  
- **Summary (excerpt):** Review discussing modulatory mechanisms of hippocampal plasticity relevant to learning and memory (PubMed page returned by the search tool).

web_search.ai_response:
## Summary — NEURON simulation software

**NEURON** is a widely used, open‑source simulation environment for modeling individual neurons and neural networks. It supports building biologically detailed single‑cell and network models, offers both a graphical interface and scripting (Python, HOC), and provides extensible biophysical mechanisms (NMODL / ChannelBuilder). It runs on local machines, HPC and cloud platforms.

---

## Key resources (official docs & guides)

- **NEURON documentation** — full docs, guides, installation, programmer reference, videos, and tutorials: [The NEURON Simulator](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/)  
- **What is NEURON** (overview & design goals): [What is NEURON](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/what_is_neuron.html)  
- **Getting started** (installation, basic usage, tutorials): [How to get started with NEURON](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/en/latest/guide/how_to_get_started.html)  
- **NEURON Python reference & examples**: see the Python docs inside the main documentation (links from the docs index).  
- **Training videos & courses**: linked from the docs (NEURON and NetPyNE recorded courses).  
- **Forum / community support**: NEURON Forum — [NEURON Forum](https://www.neuron.yale.edu/phpBB/)  
- **Model sharing / example models**: Many NEURON models are hosted on ModelDB — [ModelDB modellist for NEURON](https://modeldb.science/modellist/1882?all_simu=true)  
- **Foundational paper**: The NEURON simulation environment — [Hines & Carnevale 1997](https://doi.org/10.1162/neco.1997.9.6.1179)

---

## Installation (quick commands)

- Typical (Linux / macOS / Cloud notebooks):
  - pip: pip3 install neuron
  - On Google Colab: !pip install neuron
- Windows:
  - Use the Windows installer available on NEURON GitHub releases (or install via WSL and pip).
- Source / developer builds:
  - Source and release packages available on the NEURON GitHub: [neuronsimulator/nrn](https://github.com/neuronsimulator/nrn)

For detailed, OS‑specific instructions and troubleshooting see: [NEURON install instructions](https://nrn.readthedocs.io/install/install_instructions.html)

---

## Notable features

- Scripting with **Python** and **HOC**; GUI tools for cell building and visualization  
- User‑extendable mechanisms via **NMODL** and the GUI **ChannelBuilder** (ChannelBuilder recommended for many channel models)  
- Support for parallel/HPC simulations (MPI)  
- Rich ecosystem: example models (ModelDB), training materials, optimization tools, and active forum support

---

## Useful next steps I can do for you

- Walk through a short example (single compartment or multicompartment) in Python for NEURON and provide runnable code.  
- Retrieve installation troubleshooting steps for a specific OS (Linux/macOS/Windows/WSL).  
- Fetch specific tutorial(s) or recorded course video links from the NEURON docs.  
- Find NEURON models on ModelDB for a particular neuron type or brain region.

Which of these would you like next?

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
    if len(items) < page_size:
        break
    if total_items is not None and len(all_morphs) >= total_items:
        break

    page += 1

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(all_morphs)}\")
```

Notes:
- The entitysdk has multiple helpers; if it exposes a `.all()` or `.iterate()` convenience that automatically pages, prefer that. Example from docs: `client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()`.
- Always check the client response structure for fields like `items`, `total_items`, `limit`, `offset`, or built-in iterators.

---

## 3) Using the entitysdk convenience method shown in examples (single call)

The entitysdk examples show a convenient pattern using search_entity(...).all() to fetch results. If the SDK supports retrieving all with `.all()`, use that:

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# If the client supports .all() to fetch everything (with internal paging)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()

print(f\Total morphologies returned: {len(morphs)}\")
for m in morphs[:10]:  # show first 10
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 4) Filtering examples (by mtype or species)

You can pass query filters to narrow results (examples from docs):

- Find morphologies for a specific MType label:

```python
morphs_sr_pc = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\mtype__pref_label\": \SR_PC\"}
).all()
```

- Limit by species (scientific name):

```python
morphs_mouse = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=CellMorphology,
    query={\subject__species__name\": \Mus musculus\"}
).all()
```

---

## Important Platform / EntityCore rules (summary)

- When calling GET ALL endpoints, mention and check `total_items`. Ask before using extra pages if you need to avoid large downloads.
- The EntityCore examples show `client.search_entity(...).all()` as a convenient approach; it may already page for you.
- The SDK examples in the repo demonstrate additional workflows: uploading assets, registering morphologies, adding MType classifications \u2014 see the entitysdk examples for full patterns.

---

If you\u2019d like:
- I can produce a ready-to-run script tailored to your auth method (API key / OAuth) \u2014 tell me which auth you use.
- Or I can show an example using explicit entitycore API parameters (page, page_size) adapted to the exact client methods you have \u2014 tell me which entitysdk version or client functions you see.
software_docs_entitysdk.ai_response:
## Overview

Below are concise, practical examples to list all **CellMorphology** entities using the **entitysdk** (Open Brain Institute Entity SDK). These examples assume you already have an authenticated SDK client object named **client** (see your SDK auth docs / examples for creating the client).

---

### 1) Minimal: retrieve all morphologies (simple)

```python
# Assumes an authenticated `client` exists
# Import names (CellMorphology is the entity class used in queries)
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# Retrieve all CellMorphology entities (will page internally)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(morphs)}")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

Notes:
- `.all()` will fetch all pages for you.
- Each item `m` is a CellMorphology entity object; fields available depend on the entity representation returned by the SDK.

---

### 2) Previewing when many items exist (limit and sample)

```python
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# Fetch only 10 items (useful for quick previews)
morphs_page = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(\Preview (first 10):", len(morphs_page))
for m in morphs_page:
    print(m.id, m.name, "-", getattr(m, \description", "")[:120])
```

---

### 3) Example: print useful metadata for each morphology

```python
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()

for m in morphs:
    # Example fields commonly present on returned objects
    print(\ID:    ", m.id)
    print(\Name:  ", m.name)
    print(\Desc:  ", getattr(m, \description", None))
    print(\Species:", getattr(getattr(m, \subject", None), \species", None))
    # If brain_region is nested object:
    br = getattr(m,  rain_region", None)
    if br:
        print(\Brain region:", getattr(br, \pref_label", getattr(br, 
ame", None)))
    print("-\ * 40)
```

---

### 4) Filtering examples (species, mtype, brain region)

```python
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# By species name (scientific name)
morphs_mouse = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query={\subject__species__name":\Mus musculus"}).all()

# By mtype preferred label
morphs_mtype = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query={\mtype__pref_label":\L5_PC"}).all()

# By brain region (use the brain region's field name expected by the API)
morphs_region = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, query={ rain_region__pref_label":\primary visual area"}).all()
```

---

## Tips / Best practices

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
## Recent notable studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum

Below are recent high-impact papers and resources (2023–2025) focused on neuronal morphologies in the cerebrum / neocortex. I summarize each, give citation details and links, and embed available figures returned by the literature search.

### 1) Neuronal diversity and stereotypy at multiple scales through whole brain morphometry  
- **Authors:** Peng, Hanchuan et al.  
- **Journal / Date:** Nature Communications — 26 Nov 2024  
- **Summary:** Large-scale whole‑brain morphometry across hundreds of mouse brains. Annotated ~182k cell bodies, modeled >15k dendritic microenvironments and ~1,876 full neuron morphologies, plus ~2.63M axonal varicosities (putative boutons). Provides multi-scale datasets (cell, dendritic microenvironment, full morphology, axonal motifs) registered to the Allen CCF. Emphasizes diversity vs. stereotypy across scales.  
- **Link:** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-024-54745-6  
- **Key resource:** PDF available from article page.  
![Fig from Peng et al. 2024](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-024-54745-6/MediaObjects/41467_2024_54745_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 2) A Multi-Scale Neuron Morphometry Dataset from Peta-voxel Mouse Whole-Brain Images  
- **Authors:** Peng, Hanchuan et al.  
- **Journal / Date:** Scientific Data — 23 Apr 2025  
- **Summary:** Dataset paper accompanying peta‑voxel whole‑brain imaging and morphometry workflows. Describes production pipeline, data formats, and access to the large multi-scale morphometry dataset (registered to Allen CCF). Valuable for cross-scale morphological analyses and method re-use.  
- **Link:** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41597-025-04379-0  
![Fig from Peng et al. 2025 dataset paper](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41597-025-04379-0/MediaObjects/41597_2025_4379_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 3) An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex  
- **Authors:** Ecker, Alexander S. et al.  
- **Journal / Date:** Nature Communications — 9 Apr 2025  
- **Summary:** Data‑driven, unsupervised mapping of dendritic morphologies of >30,000 excitatory neurons from MICrONS serial EM data in mouse visual cortex. Suggests cortical excitatory dendritic morphologies form a continuum (axes of variation) rather than discrete m‑types, with layer‑ and area‑specific trends. Important for rethinking morphological classification.  
- **Link:** https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w  
![Fig from Ecker et al. 2025](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)

---

### 4) Variation and convergence in the morpho-functional properties of the mammalian neocortex (Review)  
- **Author:** Séverine Mahon  
- **Journal / Date:** Frontiers in Systems Neuroscience — 20 Jun 2024  
- **Summary:** Comparative review of neocortical neuron structure and function across mammals. Discusses how morphological features (dendritic length, spine density, arborization) scale with brain size and highlights conserved versus species‑specific adaptations. Useful for evolutionary / comparative perspective.  
- **Link / DOI:** https://doi.org/10.3389/fnsys.2024.1413780  
![Fig from Mahon 2024 review](https://images-provider.frontiersin.org/api/ipx/w=1200&f=png/https://www.frontiersin.org/files/Articles/1413780/fnsys-18-1413780-HTML/image_m/fnsys-18-1413780-g001.jpg)

---

### 5) Modeling and Simulation of Neocortical Micro- and Mesocircuitry. Part I: Anatomy (preprint / model resource)  
- **Authors:** Abdellah M., Hernando J., Eilemann S., Lapere S., Antille N., Markram H., Schürmann F.  
- **Date:** Aug 2024 (eLife reviewed preprint)  
- **Summary:** Large-scale data‑driven anatomical model of juvenile rat somatosensory cortex with ~4.2M morphologically and biophysically detailed neurons placed in an atlas and connected by ~14.2B synapses. Focuses on anatomical realism and limits of deducing connectivity from anatomy. Includes openly available subvolumes for simulation. Relevant for how morphology is used in large‑scale circuit models.  
- **Link:** https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/99688v1/pdf

---

### 6) Cell class-specific long-range axonal projections of neurons in mouse whisker-related somatosensory cortices (preprint)  
- **Authors:** Aronoff R., Petersen C.C.H.  
- **Date:** May 2024 (eLife reviewed preprint)  
- **Summary:** Brain‑wide light‑sheet imaging of genetically labeled projection neurons; quantifies layer/subclass-specific long-range axonal outputs from whisker somatosensory cortex. Demonstrates how morphological projection patterns map onto functional connectivity. Useful for linking soma/layer location and axonal morphology to circuit function.  
- **Link:** https://elifesciences.org/reviewed-preprints/97602v1/pdf

---

## Which of these would you like next?
- I can fetch the full text / PDFs for any of the open articles using the read‑paper tool (if publicly available).  
- I can extract figures, methods, or specific morphological measurements (e.g., dendritic length, branching statistics, bouton counts) from a chosen paper.  
- I can search specifically for human cerebrum morphology studies, or for morphological analyses of particular cell types (pyramidal cells, interneurons, L5 vs L2/3) or modalities (EM reconstructions, light-sheet, tracing).

If you want full‑text extraction for any of the above, tell me which paper(s) and I’ll attempt to retrieve them.

How to Simulate a Single Neuron Model on the Platform
Access Virtual Lab:

From the homepage, click the "Go to Virtual Lab" button.
Manage Projects:

Click on "Projects" in the left menu to see your projects.
Create a project if none exists.
Ensure you have credits in your project; transfer credits from your virtual lab if needed.
Build a Single Neuron Model:

Click on the "Build" column in the left panel.
Click the "Build" button in the single neuron tile.
Name your model, optionally add a description.
Select the brain region (e.g., primary somatosensory area).
Click "Start building."
Select a 3D reconstructed morphology (M model) and an existing electrical model (E model).
Filter morphologies by type (e.g., L5 TPC-A for thick tufted layer 5 pyramidal neuron).
Select the appropriate E model matching the morphology.
Save the created morph-electric model (M E model).
Simulate the Neuron Model:

Go back to your project homepage.
Click on the "Simulate" tab, then "Single Neuron."
Find your neuron model or search by name.
Click your model and press "New Simulation."
In the simulation window, pan, rotate, and zoom the neuron morphology.
Set experiment and simulation parameters.
Choose predefined current injection protocols or customize current steps.
Add multiple recording locations by clicking on the morphology or using the "Add Recording" button.
Press "Simulate" to run the simulation.
View and Save Results:

Save recordings or save them to the library for later access.

How to simulate a single neuron model (Video)

simulation_tutorial.ai_response:
## Overview — how simulation works on the Open Brain Platform

Simulations on the Open Brain Platform are model-driven experiments you create from a digital circuit (single neuron, microcircuit, region, etc.). The typical workflow is:

1. Select or build a circuit (an existing circuit or a circuit you create from atlas / neuron data).  
2. Create a simulation configuration describing initialization, stimuli, recordings, and any manipulations.  
3. Launch the simulation (the platform schedules and runs it).  
4. Monitor progress and inspect results (spike trains, voltages, population summaries, saved artifacts).  
5. Iterate: modify parameters, stimuli, or circuit composition as needed.

Below I give a practical, step-by-step guide and notes on the options you’ll commonly use.

---

## What you need before running a simulation

- **Circuit ID** (UUID) or choose/create a circuit on the platform. Circuits have scales such as *single*, *pair*, *microcircuit*, *region*, etc.  
- An idea of what you want to measure (e.g., membrane potential traces, spikes, population firing rates, synaptic currents).  
- Any experiment-specific manipulations: synaptic blockers, changes in extracellular calcium, optogenetic stimuli, changed connection probabilities, etc.

If you want, I can help construct the simulation configuration for a given circuit — just provide the circuit UUID and what you want to do.

---

## Types of simulations you can run

- **Single-neuron simulations**: intracellular current steps, channel perturbations, I–V curves.  
- **Paired neuron / small circuits**: synaptic pairing, paired-pulse, STDP protocols.  
- **Microcircuit simulations** (20+ cells): network dynamics, population responses, brief stimuli.  
- **Region / system simulations**: large-scale network activity, LFP proxies, population statistics.

---

## Key configuration components (what to specify)

When you create a simulation config you usually specify only the things that differ from defaults. Typical fields you will set:

- **initialize**  
  - type (e.g., deterministic / randomized)  
  - v_init (resting membrane potential)  
  - extracellular calcium concentration (if relevant)  
  - random_seed (for reproducibility)  
- **simulation length** (ms or seconds)  
- **neuron_sets / node_sets** — which neuron populations to include/record from (IDs or labels)  
- **stimuli**  
  - current clamps, synaptic inputs, optogenetic drives  
  - timing, amplitude, waveform  
- **recordings**  
  - what to record (spikes, somatic Vm, compartments, synaptic currents)  
  - sampling frequency / channels to store  
- **synaptic_manipulations** (optional)  
  - block or scale particular synapse types, change weights, change delays  
- **timestamps / metadata**  
  - campaign name, description, tags for provenance

Note: The platform provides reasonable defaults for many parameters; you only need to override items important for your experiment.

---

## How to create a valid simulation configuration (programmatic / API)

- The platform expects a structured simulation configuration (JSON).  
- There is a helper tool on the platform that generates a valid config from a natural-language description — it will fill defaults and ensure the JSON is valid. If you want, tell me: (a) the circuit UUID, and (b) a short description of the experiment (stimulus, recordings, duration, any manipulations). I can generate the config for you.

If you want me to do that now, please provide the circuit UUID and a brief description of exactly what you want to simulate.

---

## Launching, monitoring, and retrieving results

- Once the config is submitted, the platform schedules the job and runs it.  
- You can monitor status (queued, running, success/failure) and view logs/status messages (the platform exposes simulation metadata and timestamps).  
- After completion, results are stored as simulation artifacts: time series, spike lists, summary files, and plots. You can download them or use built-in viewers and analysis notebooks.

Programmatic endpoints exist to list simulations, get one simulation’s details, and list single-neuron simulations; these let you fetch metadata and results programmatically.

---

## Best practices and tips

- Use a fixed random seed for reproducibility if you need exact repeats.  
- Start with short runs or fewer recorded channels to debug config and stimuli before launching a long, expensive run.  
- Record only the variables you need (high sampling / many compartments increases storage and runtime).  
- Use population-level recordings (mean firing rates, LFP proxies) when scaling up to large circuits to reduce storage.  
- Keep a clear metadata/campaign description for provenance and sharing.

---

## Common pitfalls

- Forgetting to set the correct node_set / neuron_set ids — the simulation may run but record nothing.  
- Overly long simulation time or too many recorded traces leads to large outputs and slow transfer.  
- Not setting initial conditions (v_init) when you expect a particular baseline state.  
- Not specifying the extracellular calcium or receptor-specific manipulations when testing synaptic scaling.

---

## What I can do for you right now

- Generate a complete simulation configuration if you give me:
  - **Circuit UUID** (required)  
  - Short description: simulation length, stimuli (type, timing, amplitude), recordings you want (spikes, Vm, specific populations), and any manipulations (synapse block, calcium change, random_seed).  
- Review an existing simulation config and suggest optimizations.  
- Explain how to interpret common outputs (raster plots, firing-rate histograms, Vm traces).

I can’t see or interact with the platform UI itself, so I won’t be able to walk you through buttons or screens. If you want me to generate a simulation config now, paste the circuit UUID and describe the experiment you’d like to run.

software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

print(\spikes time_start, time_stop, dt:\", spikes.time_start, spikes.time_stop, spikes.dt)
print(\population names:\", spikes.population_names)

# Access soma voltage report
soma_report = snap_simulation.reports['SomaVoltage']
print(\SomaVoltage time_start, time_stop, dt:\", soma_report.time_start, soma_report.time_stop, soma_report.dt)

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe
filtered = spikes.filter(t_start=spikes.time_start, t_stop=spikes.time_stop)
print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Notes, tips and placeholders
- **Replace** <MEMODEL-ID> with the actual MEModel UUID from EntityCore.
- You need a configured db_client variable (OBI-One examples use a DB client for GridScan generation) \u2014 ensure you have credentials and environment set up as per your installation.
- If you prefer to pick an MEModel interactively or via EntityCore queries, use the platform's EntityCore helpers to get MEModel IDs (examples in the repository show interactive selection).
- The examples above are adapted from the OBI-One example notebooks:
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_simulation.ipynb
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_with_synapses_simulation.ipynb

If you want, I can:
- provide a minimal runnable script adjusted to your environment (if you give me the MEModel ID and where your db_client/config is stored),
- or show how to query EntityCore for available MEModels and pick one programmatically. Which would you like?
software_docs_obione.ai_response:
## Single-cell simulation example using **obi-one**

Below is a concise, runnable-style example that shows the typical workflow for running a single-cell (MEModel) simulation with **obi-one**: authenticate & initialize the client, select an MEModel (by ID or interactively), build a simulation configuration (timestamps, stimulus, recordings), validate the config, generate a grid-scan (even if only a single coordinate), and execute the simulation tasks.

> Prerequisites:
- Python environment with `obi_one` (obi-one), `entitysdk`, and `obi_notebook` packages installed.
- Valid credentials for the Open Brain Platform (token obtained via platform auth, here shown with the helper from examples).

### Full example script

```python
# Single-cell MEModel simulation with obi-one
# Adapted from obi-one examples (examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_simulation.ipynb)

from entitysdk import Client
from obi_auth import get_token
from obi_notebook import get_projects
import obi_one as obi

# --- 1) Authenticate and initialize DB client ---------------------------------
# Get token (production, DAF auth in example)
token = get_token(environment=\production", auth_mode=\daf")

# Get project context (interactive helper from examples)
project_context = get_projects.get_projects(token)

# Initialize entitysdk client (db_client) used by obi-one utilities
db_client = Client(environment=\production", project_context=project_context, token_manager=token)


# --- 2) Select MEModel to simulate -------------------------------------------
# Option A: Use a specific MEModel ID (replace with a real MEModel ID)
memodel_id = "<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with actual MEModel ID

# Option B (interactive helper): list/select memodel entities (examples show get_entities helper)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel", token, [], project_context=project_context, multi_select=False, default_scale=\small")


# --- 3) Build simulation configuration ---------------------------------------
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty MEModelSimulationScanConfig
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info
info = obi.Info(campaign_name=\MEModel Single-Cell Simulation",
                campaign_description=\Single-cell simulation with constant current clamp")
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info")

# Regular timestamps: here we create one repetition spanning the sim duration
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0,
                                           number_of_repetitions=1,
                                           interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name=\RegularTimestamps")

# Stimulus: Constant current clamp to soma (single amplitude)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,      # ms (duration of injection)
    amplitude=0.5,        # nA
    timestamp_offset=0.0
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput")

# Record soma voltage for the time window of the stimulus
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name=\VoltageRecording")

time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name=\TimeWindowVoltageRecording")

# Initialization: point the simulation to the MEModel by ID
initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=memodel_id),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(initialize, name=\initialize")


# --- 4) Validate the config --------------------------------------------------
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()


# --- 5) Generate and execute a grid scan (even for single coordinate) --------
# Create the GridScanGenerationTask. Output root can be any writeable path.
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX",
    output_root="./obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan"
)

# Optional: inspect parameters that will generate coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (this writes scan/coordinate directories to output_root)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```
